label: 毘沙門, 毘沙門天
本: Jewel in the Ashes: Buddha Relics and Power in Early Medieval Japan . Harvard University Asia Center . 2000
見出し読み: びしゃもん, びしゃもんてん
説明文: Bishamon(ten) 毘沙門（天）, also referred to as Beishiramana [-(b)ana] (吠室羅末拏), Bisharamon (毘舎羅門), Tamon (多聞), Kubeira (倶吠羅), Konpira (金毘羅), Kubira bishamon (拘毘羅毘沙門).  Bishamon, called Vaiśravaṇa in India, guards the north as one of the celestial four deity-kings of the cardinal directions.  Associated with victory in battle, Bishamon was also believed capable of bringing success to a variety of endeavors.  Often carryinhg a bejeweled stūpa in his left hand, his image was installed in temples such as Kuramadera and above the Rashōmon gate in Heian-kyō (Kyoto) during the Heian era (the latter later removed to Tōji). He was the object of esoteric Buddhist rites by the mid-Heian era, and was laterincluded among the 7 deities  of good fortune.
